Award.AbstractNarration:
This project focuses on a fundamental research challenge of modern nuclear physics, namely to understand the structure and interactions of the basic building blocks of the visible matter, protons and neutrons known collectively as nucleons, in terms of Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD), the theory of the strong forces in nature. Nucleons, are composed of a variety of quarks confined by the quanta of the strong nuclear fields known as gluons. In order to explore the nucleon structure we perform electron scattering experiments where sophisticated particle detectors are utilized as powerful microscopes in order to determine the detailed dynamics of quark constituents. This in turn provides an important input for testing and understanding QCD.

This project involves four experimental activities, three of which will take place at the Thomas Jefferson National Accelerator Facility (TJNAF) while the fourth one will occur at the MAMI Microtron in Mainz, Germany. At TJNAF, first, a high precision measurement of the nucleon excitation to the Delta resonance will shed light on the mechanisms responsible for the presence of non-spherical components in the nucleon wave-function, with an emphasis on the role of the pion cloud to the nucleon dynamics. Second, in a separate experiment we will explore deep inelastic electron scattering off triton (2 neutrons + 1 proton) and helium-3 (1 neutron + 2 protons) mirror nuclei to determine the ratio of the up over down valence quark momentum distributions in a free proton, and advance our understanding of the effect of the nuclear medium on these momentum distributions. Third, a measurement of the J/Psi meson electroproduction cross section near threshold off a proton will enable us to explore the non-perturbative gluonic interaction between the J/Psi and the proton. This measurement might reveal an enhancement of the cross section just above threshold which could be indicative of the important role conformal anomaly contribution plays in QCD.

At the MAMI Microtron, the first high precision measurement of the Virtual Compton Scattering reaction on the nucleon resonance will allow the investigation of the electric generalized polarizability of the proton, meaning how stiffly the nucleon responds to an external electric field. The experiment will also allow for the first exploration of the nucleon excitation through a purely electromagnetic photon channel.

The project will enhance the infrastructure for research by building instrumentation for nuclear physics experiments, primarily at TJNAF, and by supporting international collaborative research efforts. The research activities will also contribute to science education by providing topics for PhD theses in nuclear physics, thus training a new generation of nuclear scientists. Furthermore, the opportunities for training students at the undergraduate level with hands on hardware experience will advance nuclear science education, which is essential to ensure a broad, basic knowledge of nuclear science in society.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Understanding the structure of hadrons in terms of the underlying constituents, the quarks and gluons, is one of the central goals of modern nuclear physics. The underlying theory of strong interactions, quantum chromodynamics (QCD), is difficult to solve and precise experiments are needed to test the theoretical predictions of QCD and to provide guidance towards its further improvement. This award has supported a number of experimental activities at the Thomas Jefferson National Accelerator Facility (JLab), at the MAMI Microtron, and at PSI, which focus on studying various aspects of the hadronic structure. 

The Generalized Polarizabilities (GPs) of the proton are elementary structure constants that describe the response of the system to a static electromagnetic field and they quantify the deformation of the charge and magnetization distributions inside the proton caused by the electric or magnetic field, respectively. The electric GP has attracted a lot of attention in recent years since the first generation of experiments have revealed an unexpected structure. Under the support of this award one experiment at MAMI has already offered new experimental evidence that will allow to resolve the electric GP puzzle, while one new experimental program at JLab has been initiated that will further explore the electric and the magnetic GPs of the proton.

The excitation mechanism of the nucleon has been explored through studies of the first nucleon resonance at JLab and at MAMI. These experiments have extended the measurements of the transition form factors to a new lowest momentum transfer region and they have offered the first high precision measurements through the photon excitation channel. The results from these experiments have contributed valuable information for understanding the interplay of the mesonic and quark-gluon degrees of freedom to the nucleon dynamics.

Another recent topic of interest to the nuclear physics community is the proton radius puzzle, the difference between the radius when measured with electrons vs. muon probes. This discrepancy has attracted a lot of attention since it might result from beyond standard model physics, while explanations invoking novel aspects of nucleon structure or issues with the extraction of the radius from the experiments are also possible. The MUSE experiment at the Paul Scherrer Institute πM1 beam line will measure ep and μp elastic scattering simultaneously to further test lepton universality, two-photon exchange corrections, and the proton radius puzzle. MUSE is sensitive to possible explanations of the proton radius puzzle to which other experiments are insensitive. This project supported the building of equipment for the MUSE experiment, and primarily the construction of the Straw Tube Tracker detector system. The work that was accomplished in this project is critical for the success of the MUSE experiment, which in turn will allow to address a puzzle that might reflect novel physics of great importance. 

This award has also supported the initiation of a new experimental effort that focuses on the measurement of the near threshold electro-production of J/Ψ on the proton utilizing the SoLID detector at Jefferson Lab. The experiment will study the non-perturbative gluonic interaction between the J/Ψ and the nucleon and will help us understand how much of the nucleon mass is carried by the mass, kinetic and potential energy of the quarks and how much is carried by the kinetic and potential energy of the gluons and by a fundamental piece known as the "trace anomaly".

The most significant broader impact outcome of this research is the education and training of students in the field of nuclear science and in the methods of basic research. This grant supported the work of graduate and undergraduate students, offering them topics for their thesis and for research training. The project has allowed the students to broaden their perspective by working in an international collaboration, while their training will allow them to pursue careers in a variety of areas, from medical physics to national security, in addition to continued work in fundamental physics research.
